content.text: **Belief logic** (or epistemic logic) formalizes reasoning about knowledge, belief, and other **propositional attitudes**. It lets us express statements like 'Alice believes it's raining' or 'Bob knows that Alice believes it's raining'.

These operators are different from truth-functional connectives. 'Alice believes P' can be true even when P is false, and 'Alice believes P and Q' doesn't follow from 'Alice believes P' and 'Alice believes Q' being separately true.

content.definition: Bₐ(P) means 'agent a believes that P'. Unlike knowledge, belief doesn't require truth — you can believe false things.
Kₐ(P) means 'agent a knows that P'. Knowledge is traditionally defined as justified true belief, so Kₐ(P) → P (knowledge implies truth).

content.text: Important principle: Knowledge implies truth (Kₐ(P) → P), but belief doesn't. You can believe something false. Also, knowing that you know something (positive introspection) is often assumed: Kₐ(P) → Kₐ(Kₐ(P)).

content.question: Can Bₐ(P) be true while P is false?
options: Yes, you can believe false things
Only if P is about the future
Only if agent a is uncertain
content.explanation: Yes! Unlike knowledge, belief doesn't require truth. You can believe it's sunny when it's actually raining. Bₐ(P) just says agent a believes P, regardless of whether P is true.
